data.note: Suriname's electricity market is controlled by state-owned Energiebedrijven Suriname (EBS), a vertically-integrated utility that controls transmission, distribution and 41% of the country's generation capacity. Most of the remaining share is generated by the state-owned oil company, Staatsolie, and a private mining company, Suralco. According to IDB, EBS operates seven isolated systems in Suriname,SR, serving over 145,000 customers. The Energie Voorziening Paramaribo (EPAR) is the largest of EBS's power systems, serving over 129,000 customers in the Paramaribo and surrounding areas. EBS shares its responsibility for rural electrification with the Dienst Electrificatie Voorziening (DEV), the Ministry of Natural Resource's department of rural energy, which operates a total of 6.2MW small power systems in isolated and remote communities where EBS networks do not reach customers.
data.name: The power sector has been unbundled (whether privatized or not) into distinct actors for generation, transmission, distribution and retail

data.note: Suriname's electricity market is controlled by state-owned Energiebedrijven Suriname (EBS), a vertically-integrated utility that controls transmission, distribution and 41% of the country's generation capacity. Most of the remaining share is generated by the state-owned oil company, Staatsolie, and a private mining company, Suralco. According to IDB, EBS operates seven isolated systems in Suriname,SR, serving over 145,000 customers. The Energie Voorziening Paramaribo (EPAR) is the largest of EBS's power systems, serving over 129,000 customers in the Paramaribo and surrounding areas. EBS shares its responsibility for rural electrification with the Dienst Electrificatie Voorziening (DEV), the Ministry of Natural Resource's department of rural energy, which operates a total of 6.2MW small power systems in isolated and remote communities where EBS networks do not reach customers.
data.name: There are legally separate private companies at each segment of the power system pre-retail

data.note: Suriname does not have an independent transmission system operator in place.
data.name: There is an independent transmission system that dispatches according to market dynamics and is not susceptible to state interference

data.note: Suriname's average retail electricity rate is one of the lowest in Latin America and the Caribbean. Subsidies are estimated at 1.5-2% of Suriname's GDP. Additionally, consumers older than 60 years and consuming less than 150kWh/month can use the 60+ scheme.
data.name: Retail electricity prices aren't distorted by subsidies

data.note: Three companies control generation in Suriname.
data.name: There aren't significant barriers to private sector participation in generation

data.note: State-owned company Energiebedrijven Suriname (EBS) controls, energy transmission, distribution, retail and part of the generation market in Suriname.
data.name: Consumers can choose retail suppliers or third-party power marketers in the retail power market

data.note: There isn`t a wholesale power market in Suriname.
data.name: There is a functioning competitive wholesale generation market

data.note: Energy is generated by three power producers: EBS, Suralco and Staatsolie.
data.name: The generation market has many different actors and is not concentrated in the hands of a few players

data.note: EBS is the only power supplier in Suriname.
data.name: The supply market has many different actors and is not concentrated in the hands of a few players
